Barrister.definition: a lawyer who argues cases before a British court ;esp
Barrister.origin: [Middle English barrester , from barre bar + -ster (as in legister lawyer)]

1.definition: a lawyer who argues cases before a British courtone who is allowed to argue before a British high court compare
1.note: Many countries in the Commonwealth (as England and Australia) and the Republic of Ireland divide the legal profession into barristers and solicitors. In Canada, every lawyer is both a barrister and a solicitor, although individual lawyers may describe themselves as one or the other. Scotland uses the termadvocateto refer to lawyers allowed to argue cases in its courts.
